Authors:
Daryl W Lam, Timothy J. Entwisle, Pertti Eloranta, Janina
Kwandrans, Morgan L Vis
Title:
Circumscription of species in the genus Sirodotia
(Batrachospermales, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morphological
data
Keywords:
cox 2-3 spacer, freshwater, macroalgae, phylogeography,
rbcL, streams
Abstract:
Species level taxonomy and phylogeographic distribution
patterns in the freshwater rhodophyte Sirodotia Kylin are resolved
through phylogenetic inferences based on rbcL and cox2-3 sequence data.
Previous studies focused on the taxonomy of specific Sirodotia species
or the distributions across a limited geographic region. Our molecular
phylogenies include samples attributable to five recognized Sirodotia
species and include collections from Australia, Brazil, Costa Rica,
Canada, Finland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa, and the United
States. Both rbcL and cox2-3 phylogenies inferred S. suecica Kylin, S.
tenuissima (Collins) Skuja ex Flint, and S. goebelii Entwisle et Foard
as a monophyletic group with little sequence divergence. This result
supports the synonymy of S. tenuissima and S. goebelii with S. suecica
(the species name with priority). Within the aforementioned clade,
samples collected from Australia and New Zealand formed a monophyletic
group with no other discernible phylogeographic patterns within S.
suecica. This result seems to be somewhat unusual in the
Batrachospermales as other species have shown greater genetic variation
among geographically distant locations. Like previous studies, S.
huillensis (Welwitsch ex W. & G.S. West) Skuja and S. delicatula
Skuja were inferred as a separate species based on the rbcL phylogeny
and supports the current taxonomy. A specimen labeled S. aff. huillensis
from South Africa, may represent a new species, however, further
research is necessary before it can be designated as such.
